CheckTitle: Amazon Cognito user pool client has token revocation enabled
CheckType: Software and Configuration Checks/AWS Security Best Practices
Software and Configuration Checks/Industry and Regulatory Standards/AWS Foundational Security Best Practices
Description:
**Amazon Cognito user pool app clients** are evaluated for **token revocation** being enabled via `EnableTokenRevocation`.

This identifies whether each client can invalidate refresh tokens and the access/ID tokens derived from them to end user sessions.
Risk: Without **token revocation**, stolen or residual refresh tokens remain valid until expiry, enabling continued access after sign-out or account disablement. This undermines **confidentiality** and **integrity** by permitting unauthorized API calls, data exfiltration, and session hijacking.

Code.NativeIaC:
```yaml
Resources:
  <example_resource_name>:
    Type: AWS::Cognito::UserPoolClient
    Properties:
      UserPoolId: "<example_resource_id>"
      EnableTokenRevocation: true  # Critical: Enables token revocation so the client passes the check
```
Code.Other:
1. In the AWS Console, go to Amazon Cognito > User pools
2. Select your user pool, then open App integration > App clients
3. Click the target app client and choose Edit
4. Under Advanced configuration, enable Token revocation
5. Click Save changes
Code.Terraform:
```hcl
resource "aws_cognito_user_pool_client" "<example_resource_name>" {
  name                    = "<example_resource_name>"
  user_pool_id            = "<example_resource_id>"
  enable_token_revocation = true  # Critical: Enables token revocation so the client passes the check
}
```

Recommendation.Text:
Enable `EnableTokenRevocation: true` on all app clients.

Also:
- Use refresh token rotation
- Shorten token lifetimes
- Apply least privilege to scopes
- Enforce user/admin sign-out to terminate sessions
- Monitor for anomalous token reuse
